snippet: Cases of H5N1 have inexplicably increased, and a study of genetic sequences in victims shows some mutations that may make humans more susceptible.
abstract: Study in journal mBio finds that strains of H5N1 avian flu in Egypt, which has surpassed Indonesia as country with most human cases of virus, carry mutations that may make it easier for it to attach to human airway cells or to reproduce there; results raise concerns that virus could rapidly adapt to human airway microenvironment.
lead_paragraph: Cases of H5N1 have inexplicably increased, and a study of genetic sequences in victims shows some mutations that may make humans more susceptible.

headline.print_headline: Egypt’s Avian Flu Surge Lacks an Explanation
headline.main: Egypt’s Avian Flu Surge Lacks an Explanation
